543. Wilson (Mrs. Robert Edward)
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual has been asked to answer; each has exactly the same experiences as another.

Some of the questions have been answered by others who may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The answers of those who have answered them will help to answer the questions.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Farmers Enjoy?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. With or without this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual has been able to answer all questions exactly the same as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The objective of this form is not to collect sufficient data to answer the question, but to stimulate thought, discussion, or debate. The particular event, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be printed at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They didn't think much of it and never expected to see us again. We will and they certainly came to see us much later.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
My father and mother and I came together.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
By train and by ship. We came by ship.

14. How long did it take to cross the ocean? I think it was a sailing vessel. Then by rail to Regina.

15. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement?)

16. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

As a clergyman.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They didn't think much of it and never expected us to see again. We wrote and they rarely came to see us much later.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

My father and mother and I came together.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We took an 8-week trip across the ocean by ship.

It was a sailing vessel. Then by rail to Regina.

14. What highlights of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement)

Our luggage was delayed partly due to a railway strike. It never caught up in the rear of the train from Regina to Carlton.

The family was friendly and never bothered us. We shared a team of horses and helped each other with the work.

Railway

Regina

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

For three months.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

No mi east of Regina.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We came to Bellevue in 1899. In 1914 after homesteading 1 mi. From Bellevue.

The government family cemetery is still there.

Clothing on the little house was very simple.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

As a clergyman.

As a farmer and miner.

5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Very few. Some moved into town.

None of the farmers stayed and raised their families and farms.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Not so many. Some came back.

My husband was Reeve and Councilor for two years also. He organized the club in 1915 and was chairman until 1917.
